                <h1>About photography</h1>
                <p>Photography is both a technical craft and a quiet way of thinking about the world. At its simplest,
                    it records
                    light striking a surface, but at its best, it captures moments that might otherwise
                    disappear—fleeting
                    expressions, ordinary scenes, or the subtle moods of a place. A photograph freezes time, allowing us
                    to look
                    longer and more carefully than real life usually permits.
                    Beyond documentation, photography is a form of interpretation. Every choice the photographer
                    makes—framing,
                    timing, focus, and distance—shapes how a subject is understood. Two people can photograph the same
                    scene and
                    produce entirely different meanings, revealing that photographs are not neutral copies of reality
                    but personal
                    perspectives rendered in light and shadow.
                    Photography also plays a powerful social role. It preserves memory, challenges assumptions, and can
                    expose
                    injustice or beauty with equal force. From family albums to photojournalism and fine art,
                    photographs connect
                    personal experience to collective history. In doing so, photography reminds us that seeing is not
                    just a
                    physical act, but an emotional and ethical one.</p>
                <h2>Image examples of photography</h2>
                <img src="data:image/jpeg;base64," width="400" height="400">
                <div>
                    <img src="data:image/jpeg;base64," width="400" height="400">
                </div>

                </div>
                <h3>Expressions of photography</h3>
                <p>Photography can express a *lot*—it’s basically a visual language. Here are some common **expressions
                    of
                    photography**, grouped by what they tend to communicate:

                </p><div> Emotional Expression </div>

                <div>Photography can convey feelings without words: </div>

                * Joy, love, intimacy
                * Loneliness, grief, nostalgia
                * Fear, tension, mystery
                * Peace, calm, hope

                A single glance, shadow, or color choice can carry the emotion.

                <div>Storytelling &amp; Narrative</div>

                Photos can tell stories:

                * Daily life and culture (street photography)
                * Personal journeys or identity
                * Social issues, conflict, resilience
                * Moments before/after an event (implied stories)

                <div>Artistic Expression</div>

                Photography as art focuses on creativity:

                * Abstract forms, patterns, textures
                * Experimental lighting or motion
                * Conceptual photography (ideas &gt; realism)
                * Minimalism or surrealism

                <div>Perspective &amp; Interpretation</div>

                It shows *how the photographer sees the world*:

                * Unique angles or framing
                * What’s included vs. excluded
                * Juxtaposition and contrast
                * Symbolism and metaphor

                <div>Documentary &amp; Truth</div>

                Photography as evidence or record:

                * Photojournalism
                * Historical documentation
                * Environmental and social awareness
                * Portraits capturing real people and lives

                <div>Identity &amp; Self-Expression</div>

                Used to explore who we are:

                * Self-portraits
                * Fashion and lifestyle photography
                * Cultural and gender identity
                * Personal memory and autobiography

                <div>Mood &amp; Atmosphere</div>

                Created through visual elements:

                * Light (soft, harsh, dramatic)
                * Color (warm, cold, muted, bold)
                * Focus, blur, grain
                * Weather and environment


                <p></p>
            <!-- Code injected by live-server -->
<script>
	// <![CDATA[  <-- For SVG support
	if ('WebSocket' in window) {
		(function () {
			function refreshCSS() {
				var sheets = [].slice.call(document.getElementsByTagName("link"));
				var head = document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0];
				for (var i = 0; i < sheets.length; ++i) {
					var elem = sheets[i];
					var parent = elem.parentElement || head;
					parent.removeChild(elem);
					var rel = elem.rel;
					if (elem.href && typeof rel != "string" || rel.length == 0 || rel.toLowerCase() == "stylesheet") {
						var url = elem.href.replace(/(&|\?)_cacheOverride=\d+/, '');
						elem.href = url + (url.indexOf('?') >= 0 ? '&' : '?') + '_cacheOverride=' + (new Date().valueOf());
					}
					parent.appendChild(elem);
				}
			}
			var protocol = window.location.protocol === 'http:' ? 'ws://' : 'wss://';
			var address = protocol + window.location.host + window.location.pathname + '/ws';
			var socket = new WebSocket(address);
			socket.onmessage = function (msg) {
				if (msg.data == 'reload') window.location.reload();
				else if (msg.data == 'refreshcss') refreshCSS();
			};
			if (sessionStorage && !sessionStorage.getItem('IsThisFirstTime_Log_From_LiveServer')) {
				console.log('Live reload enabled.');
				sessionStorage.setItem('IsThisFirstTime_Log_From_LiveServer', true);
			}
		})();
	}
	else {
		console.error('Upgrade your browser. This Browser is NOT supported WebSocket for Live-Reloading.');
	}
	// ]]>
</script>
